text: We will hear arguments next in 5935 Durst against the United States.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
It was just an ordinary you are talking about.
Mr. Attorney General Biddle --
That was a letter from the Attorney General of the United States.
Not an ordinary letter.
It gives me a straight impression, it was just a letter.
Well, it was a letter written to the House Committee considering the bill, I believe, transmitted from the Judicial Conference considered to the Youth Act.
Yeah, from the Attorney General of the United States.
That is correct Your Honor.
And it said explicitly, a fine was to be included.
That is correct with reference to be Your Honor.
And that was the reason for the amendment.
That is correct Your Honor.
Have you anything against that, any legislative history to contradict that?
No, I do not Your Honor.
What about restitution?
No Your Honor.
Very well.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
Does 3651 permit the imposition and fine as a condition of probation when the underlying statute does not impose a fine?
Mr. McCree: I would not so contend.
Doesnâ€™t this case simply go for sentence the amount of that provision?
No, they do not sentence the amount of that provision but that --
What under 3651?
Well, 3651 incorporates the offense that was committed that brought the person before the Court by reason of the indictment.
Thank you Mr. Solicitor General.
